Entry.0:
Saturday 1916

New Years day, played cards all day & won about 10/-. Stayed at home all day, had a very quiet time.

Sunday 

Had a very quiet day, lay about & read & went for a walk in the afternoon.

Monday 3 January, 1916

Went out to Pieta in the afternoon & had a good time. Left early & went to the Olympia Club & met a Marine Corporal named Baseby. We had a good few drinks & a game of billiards. After that they asked me to stay out of camp overnight so we went across the grand harbour in a dicer but I could not get a bed so I had to make my way back to camp, about 6 miles & across two harbours. I eventually arrived home safely at about 12.30.

Tuesday 4 January 1916

Left All Saints camp at 11.30 a.m. to embark for Alexandria. Embarked on H.T. "Bornu" at 3.30 p.m. She is rather an old boat & looks as if she will roll a lot.

We expect to sail early in the morning.

Wednesday 5 January, 1916

Sailed at 6.30.

The "Bornu" is a bad sea ship & had made a lot of the boys sick. I am all right so far.

Was on Night Guard, on guard from 8 to 10.30 p.m. & from 2.30 a.m. to 4.30. So I did not get much sleep.

The weather is very calm.
Entry.1:
Feeling a bit tired. The weather is beginning to get windy with a promise of rain.

Rain came on late in the afternoon & the sea got up a good deal. It is a pitch dark night & the boat is rolling horribly. We have as escort a little trawler which carries two light guns. She is rolling all over the place & shipping a lot of water. We have to have our lifebelts with us all the time & are all told off to certain boats in case of being torpedoed. I am in No 13 mess & 13 boat so according to anyone of a superstitious nature I don't stand much chance of pulling through if anything happens.
Entry.2:
The wind & rain continues, the sea is getting very rough & it is nearly impossible to stand on deck. Most of the chaps are seasick, I am not feeling too happy myself but I am not at all ill.

It is becoming a juggling trick to eat your meals nowadays, you dare not take your hand off your plate for a moment & have to eat with the other.

It has been raining on & off all the morning but after dinner the wind went down & the sun showed up a bit though the sea is still rough.
Entry.3:
The sea is calming down a great deal & things are almost normal again. Our escort, the little trawler is having engine trouble & this is keeping us back.

We play a lot of bridge it is about the only way of putting in the time.
Entry.4:
The weather was dirty early in the morning but during the afternoon it has been lovely, even the birds, we have some canaries on board seem happy & all singing away.

The air is warm & the sea is a lovely blue, it is a delight to be on it even if you are in an old tub of a transport.

We came in sight of land towards evening but did not go into harbour.
Entry.5:
We were cruising around all night & ran into Alexandria at about 9.30 a.m.

Lay in the harbour all day, we are very anxious to get ashore which we won't do till tomorrow, we are lying near the entrance to the harbour & have some fine scenery to look at.
Entry.6:
Were towed up the harbour to 28 wharf, the Tommies got off in the morning but we had to wait till afternoon.

Were taken to "A" Camp Gabbari at Alexandria, our officers left us standing & went off. We had neither food nor bedding, we managed to get something to eat off some kind hearted Tommies & had to put on as many pieces of extra clothing as we could to bunk amongst some horse fodder in the Veterinary store. We were pretty cold & uncomfortable.
Entry.7:
Still at a loose end nobody loves us & nobody wants us. The camp adjutant has turned out a brick & is trying to get us bedding & money. We got 8/- each &our bedding so we are all right. No leave has been given but we have taken a look round Alex, we have no time to do the thing thoughly but from what I can see it is a much finer place than Cairo though not as large.

We got unspecified orders to be ready to move off at 11 p.m., most of our boys were the worse for the 8/- but we got away all right, 130 of us with no one in charge & are now on our way to Cairo. Hooray, I will soon be back with the boys.

Thursday 13 January, 1916

Arrived safely at Tel-El-Kebir at 8.30 a.m. Mac was O.K. I went straight on duty. It is great to be back at it once more, 5 brigades are here with Artillery & Light horse.

Received 6 parcels, had more than I knew what to do with but you may be sure that nothing was wasted.

Went & saw Bob Dryden, he is well.

Best of all I received 25 letters, I had a gay old time reading them.

The Dervish trenches are only 5 minutes walk from the camp where the battle of Tel-El-Kebir was fought in the Egyptian War of 1882.

Friday 14 January, 1916

Got some more letters today, I am in luck. The dainties out of the parcels are going fast & are highly appreciated.

We do our work on the desert wich is much harder than that round Cairo & all covered with stones.

The country here is very flat looking away towards the canal & all hummocky towards the desert. We get it cold here in the morning but it is lovely & warm later on.

Saturday 15 January, 1916

Big things doing. Brigade inspection in the morning, by the afternoon all the troops were inspected by Sir Archibald Murray. He was very pleased with our turnout.

Sunday 16 January, 1916

Church parade in the morning. Went to see Frank Isaac & the boys after dinner.

Monday 17 January, 1916

Passed standard tests in Machine Gun school.

Tuesday 18 January, 1916

Raining on & off, going on to more advanced work with the guns.

Wednesday 19 January, 1916

Drilled in the morning & had a half holiday in the afternoon. Young Gribble came up to see me & we both went to see Mr Wright but he was busy so we didn't bother.

Thursday 20 January, 1916

Have been out at the range all day, fell in at 7.15 & got home about 7 p.m. We had to march 3 miles there & back, I came back half way on a limber as I have been crook lately.

Friday 21 January, 1916

Pretty tired after yesterdays work nothing much doing, fooling round signalling & cutting out time.

Saturday 22 January, 1916

Very slack day, fooled round all the time. We heard that we are leaving here tomorrow but do not know how true it is.

Sunday 23 January, 1916

Mess orderly today.

All the G'burn boys had their photos taken with Major Fitzgerald.

Got orders to move. Struck tents at 4.30 p.m., lay in our overcoats till 12.45, moved off 1.20 a.m. went by train to Ismailia. Marched from there to Ferry Post about 4 miles.

Our Pack was 250 rounds of ammunition, 2 blankets & waterproof sheet & all spare clothes etc something like 120 lbs.

Monday 24 January, 1916

We marched on to our camping ground dead beat & fell down where we stood. About an hour later the tents came so we pitched tents & had some breakfast. After that I payed a visit to the canteen & bought a few eatables.

Went to bed at about 6.30.

Tuesday 25 January, 1916

Went down to the canteen for bread, nothing doing so I went into Ismailia, had a very fine time, arrived home at about 4.30 p.m. with 3 loaves of bread.

Wednesday 26 January, 1916

I have struck some tough goes out here, but today has been about as bad as any. The only thing in its favour was that it was sharp & short. It was a 6 hour nightmare.

We left Ferry post at about 9 a.m. & struck out in the desert towards the trenches with a full pack & from then it became a ceaseless struggle through the sand & rain till 4 p.m. I was at my last gasp several times but I managed to keep up with the column, through the ankle deep sand & ended dead beat like every one else. We are now camped in the sand with the prospect of stopping there till after the Turks have made their dash.

Thursday 27 January, 1916

Our position is in Pinchgut Hollow, in the 2nd line of defence. There are 14 men in our tent.

It is wet & miserable, only half the Battalion is here the remainder are at Tel-El-Kebir.

Friday 28 January, 1916

We have had to live on bully beef, biscuits & cheese all the time & very little of that. I wrote a letter to the mater telling her all about our getting here but it was returned by censor who will not let us say anything about being this side of the canal.

A chap from the A.M.C. went into Ismalia with sick & we have given him some cash to bring us back something to eat & some cigarettes.

The bad tucker is bringing on my old complaint again.

Saturday 29 January, 1916

Am crook with Dysentery.

Our extra tucker came today so everybody is happy.

Some of the chaps say you are better off in gaol as you do get bread there & they are not far out; it is worse here than in the Peninsula both for water & food.

Sunday 30 January, 1916

Church parade in the morning.

Played the Signallers football & beat them 9 to nil. Too much of a crowd in the tent so I slept outside.

Finished all our extra tucker, are waiting for the next man to go into civilisation. Feeling O.K. again.

Monday 31 January, 1916

Am tent orderly today, have had some very interesting work on the guns, doing "tactical handling" in the field; taking up positions without being seen.

We are all a bit stiff after the football yesterday.

Tuesday 1 February, 1916

Feeling better today.

It gets very monotomous in this hole. We have to drill just for appearances sake & we are all heartly sick of it as the tucker is very scarce & extremely rough.

Stew & biscuits being about the most apertising dish we have served up to us & when there is not a sign of vegetable in the stew & the biscuits refuse to submit to mastrication till they have been thoroughly soaked you may guess it is no first class hotel out this way.

Wednesday 2 February, 1916

Drill in the morning, half holiday in the afternoon, we played a draw at football with the signallers. Mac & I were not playing. Mac had a crook leg & a bad eye & I was too shaky from Dysentery.

Our mail arrived today. I got about 8 letters, one batch being mail that has been following me round for some time.

Thursday 3 February, 1916

The two companies, C & D, that were left at Tel-El-Kebir arrived here today.

They had the same march as we had & were pretty tired & many had left their blankets behind.

Friday 4 February, 1916

Am off duty today.

There was a bit of a mutiny in C. Company today, the men refused to put on their packs to go out on parade, it ended up by the men going out as they were ordered with 13 left behind in the guard tent.

Saturday 5 February, 1916

Wet day.

Tucker no good. Could not even get a biscuit to eat, have never been so short since I joined the army.

4th Reinforcements arrived today. Holloway came with them.



Sunday 6 February, 1916

Tucker getting very scarce. 1/4th tins of jam & 1/6th of a tin of bully per man with biscuits & about¼ lb of meat for one day.

An aeroplane flew over the camp this morning. She was a big British machine & was flying very low, evidently scouting for Turks.

Monday 7 February, 1916

Sadness in the tucker line. Dinner 1½ biscuits each, 1 tin of jam between 11 men & 1 pannican of tea. (Indigestion is very scarce in this camp.)

Another aeroplane came over today & scouted round for about half & hour.

The railway is right up to us now & timber & matting is beginning to come in for the trenches.

We had our tea tonight listening to the strains of music produced by the band. We would rather have them put a little more sugar in the tea or make it an extra tin of jam per day if they are trying to make our meals more pleasant; music is so unsatisfactory as an item of your diet.

Tuesday 8 February, 1916

Warm day, was tent orderly. Stayed in in the morning. Went out in the afternoon & hurt my back lifting the gun & tripod.

Wednesday 9 February, 1916

The day is cold, wet & miserable & so am I. I am out of humour with everything & everyone, it is because I am feeling so crook but I suppose it will all come right in the end.

Thursday 10 February, 1916

Things are a bit brighter today. I am feeling a bit better. We got ½ loaf of bread per man.

Today is the first day that the heat has had a sting in it. We all had our coats off on the afternoon parade.

The Companies have put on an extra spurt with the trench digging & the aeroplanes are up every day. We hear all sorts of rumours of where the Turks are, varying from 7000 yds to forty miles but none are to be relied upon.

Friday 11 February, 1916

Felt very off in the morning but bucked up in the afternoon.

Our tucker was of the starvation order again today, tea & dry bread for dinner & no spuds in the stew for breakfast.

It has been a beautiful clear day today, from our drilling ground at the trenches we could look over some 10 miles of sand hillocks & desert bush to the dark purple ribbon of the canal, it is most distinct, you can clearly see where it widens out at the Bitter Lakes with the town of Ismailia there still further in the distance. At present there is a cargo steamer lying at Ferry Post while the 4 funnels & tapering masts of a large cruiser peep shyly over the smooth summit of a far distant sand dune while the mutter of her guns floats fitfully to our ears on the heavy desert air. Further to the South on the Suez side the land rises to the nearest approach we can see to a purple line of hills. Such is our piece of desert scenery from pinchgut.

Saturday 12 February, 1916

Pay day, drew £3. It has been a hot day with wind.
Entry.8:
Got fed up with camp so decided to walk to Ismailia to get a good feed. I covered 26 miles, 2/3 of which was desert, in 11 hours (some going).

Left camp 12 midday arrived at Ismailia about 3.30, left for home about 7 p.m. arrivedat 11 p.m.

In town I met Harry Glover who is a 1st Lieut in the 2nd division artillery. I also met Bombadier Baseby & his friend Ives from the Egmont (for our last meeting see Monday Jan 3rd '16). We had a good yarn & something to eat in lieu of a drink, we were very pleased to see each other again & he invited me on board Egmont.

The walk I did today is the stiffest I have ever tackled & I feel quite proud of myself. I also met -- Robinson, a friend of Ken Hamiltons. It is a small world.
Entry.9:
Pretty tired today, was tent orderly.

The tucker is a bit off, no water today or yesterday either so we are pretty dry.

I only got 3 letters this mail so I am feeling rather glum but you have to grin & bear it.

Tuesday 15 February, 1916

Wet day, the first for about a week. It was not enough to keep us off parade so we stripped the gun in the tent.

Dinner was painful today, no tea & no water. Dry bread & jam isn't a sumptuous repast whichever way you look at it, but its all in the game & you're got to keep smiling.

Wednesday 16 February, 1916

It rained a little in the afternoon but it didn't matter as it was our half holiday.

We had some rather good tucker today, bacon for dinner also a ration of cheese & raisons.

We are very expectant today. We have heard that that a big mail is due tomorrow & that a lot of stores we ordered from the canteen is coming in the morning. To cap it all we have been told that leave for 48 hours to 3% 
leave
 of the men is being granted soon so we are quite excted.

Bob Harris & Andy Luke went to hospital with mumps.

Our canteen stuff arrived tonight. Had a feed on the strength of it.

Thursday 17 February, 1916

Went up to see the Doc about a bad cold.

Bob Harris
&

Was disappointed as to the mail, three letters only, I expected a lot more.

Friday 18 February, 1916

Had two trips over to the right half of the 20th Batt for another gun & tripod, we saw some fine desert scenery round Australia Hill.

In the evening we moved camp & I was put in a different tent to Mac & Bernie, it feels strange being away from them.

Two of our chaps, "Sis" Ellis & Bingham had a fight, Bingham won. It is the first fight we have had in the M.G.S. .

Saturday 19 February, 1916

Am not sure whether I am sickening for the mumps or not.

This afternoon we were inspected by Genl. Legge who said there was a chance of us going to France. He read us a lecture on discipline which I hope does some good as we are very lax in that respect.

Sunday 20 February, 1916

Had the strangest church parade I have ever taken part in. It was in the midst of wind & rain. We sang the first hymn & then had to retire in a hurry because of the rain. We emerged however a few minutes later clad in our great coats & went on from the general confession.

All our services are held in the open air with the regiment drawn up in hollow square. The Colonel & adjutant sit in the centre with the officers in front in review order.

Monday 21 February, 1916

We have been living on the fat of the land for the last six days, what with our canteen stuff & the comfort fund we have had a high old time but all our good things have gone now, I finished my last tin of fish today.

Lieut Hamilton came back to the section today, he is fatter than ever.

Was mess orderly today.

Tuesday 22 February, 1916

"Hammy" lead off well by making us carry all our equipment on all parades, needless to say we were all duly pleased. The only way for him to keep our pleasure within reasonable bounds is by leaving us alone for a while.

Wednesday 23 February, 1916

Started digging gun pits. We are digging No 1 Position it is on the left of "B" Company's trenches. There are four of us & the Sergeant. We have a mile walk from the camp before we start work - full kit - & a walk of the same distance back. An engineer is in charge of the job.

We had our half holiday & we needed it, it is hard work shovelling sand.

Thursday 24 February, 1916

At it again this morning. We are hard at it, shovelling sand and filling sand bags. The sun is very warm, we strip to the waist for the sake of more freedom.

Sand work is a great trial on the temper. You work hard for an hour & throw out a huge heap of sand only to have it all tumble in again, half burying you. It gives you free play for pure Australian language. All the same we are making good headway.

Got a parcel from the mater & it was most welcome. I was feeling a bit down on it & it cheered me up.

Friday 25 February, 1916

We put in the finishing touches on our pit but we still have about 20 yards of communication trench to do & 2 dugouts to put in.

We are getting used to the walking back & forward to the job also to the hard work & my back is beginning to show less signs of complaining than at first.

I managed to get a pair of sox & a balaclava cap from the comforts fund.

Saturday 26 February, 1916

We haven't been killing ourselves today. We are further advanced than any of the other pits so are taking it easy.

We are being well fed lately & have plenty of water. We have nooccassion to grumble & yet we do. It is a soldiers privelige. Personally I don't mind it out here now, only that I am anxious to get home again & I don't suppose I shall be decently happy till I get there.

Sunday 27 February, 1916

Had to work in the morning. No church parade today. We had a concert in the afternoon. The men came back from the Zeitoun Machine Gun School at dinner time all except 1 man got instructors ticket.

Monday 28 February, 1916

We are to have the machine guns of the Brigade, are going to be formed into one company. Lewis guns will take the place of the maxims in the Battalions. Tub and I have taken on the job of scouts. We will be on Headquarters staff & big kits. This change takes place from the 1st March.

Tuesday 29 February, 1916

Pay day (£2).

We finished off our Gun pit alltogether this morning & went out on another job in the afternoon.

I am feeling very tired. All the hard work is beginning to tell. Thank goodness today is the last time we will be digging.

We are moving over to brigade Headquarters tomorrow.

Wednesday 1 March, 1916

Worked in the morning. We got all ready to move over to Brigade headquarters but had them cancelled at the last moment & we had to repack our gear. The reason that we could not go was that we could not leave the Battalion without guns & had to wait till the new Lewis guns arrived which will be in about a weeks time.

Thursday 2 March, 1916

The sand is everywhere as the wind has sprung up, we were out digging in the morning & were almost smothered. In the afternoon it became so bad that we couldn't be taken out.

The sand flies about just like rain, cutting our face & hands not to mention filling our eyes & ears.

Gambling is going on hot & strong 50 piastre notes (£ - 10/-) floating about all over the place. All is fine fun. I am going easy myself as I have leave to go to Cairo tomorrow & do not intend to lose that over a game of cards.

Friday 3 March, 1916

Got leave to go to Cairo. We have done no work today owing to the dust storms so the boys have been playing cards all day. I didn't as I want my cash to go to town.

Saturday 4 March, 1916

Now I must say goodbye to my little diary, the recorder of my pleasures & hardships & the times of peace & war through which it has been my lot to pass since leaving my civilian life for the sterner one of a soldier.

I am sending it on a long journey which I hope to make myself ere long but if perchance I am long in coming this little book will tell in brief what my fortunes have been in these distant lands to which the call of the Flag has led me.

God grant us a speedy victory & a safe return with honour.

L.K. Stuart

Saturday 6 March 1915

Sunday 7 March, 1915

Monday 8 March, 1915

Tuesday 9 March, 1915

Wednesday 10 March, 1915

Thursday 11 March, 1915

Friday 12 March, 1915

Saturday 13 March, 1915

Sunday 14 March, 1915
Entry.13: Left Goulburn to enlist in A.I.F.
Entry.17:
Tuesday 23 March, 1915

Enlisted in A.I.F. for Service abroad.

Left Barracks at 1.45 pm.

Entrained for Liverpool at 3 pm and detrained for at 4.15 pm.

Transferred to 19 Batt.

Hours

Reveille

6 am

Parade

6.30 am

Breakfast

8 am

Parade

9.15 am

Dinner

12.45 pm

Parade

2.15 pm

Parade dismissed

4.15 pm

Tea
Entry.24:
The 5th Brigade handed over to Colonel Holmes.

19th Batt Col Watson
Entry.29: Left Liverpool by the 7-6 pm train for Goulburn, arrived at Goulburn 12.25 am
Entry.32: Left Home for Camp at 12.20 am train arrived at Camp at 5.15 am
Entry.33: Father & Frank, Mrs Stuart and Dalplen Ferguson cameout to the Camp.
Entry.41:
Went to see a Boxing Match well worth seeing.

Johnson v Wilson
Entry.44: Les and I went to the City to see Nola at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital.
Entry.46: C Coy 19 Batt on Duty, Beavers in charge of Pioneer fatigue.
Entry.47:
The Fifth Brigade comprising the 17/18/19 Battalions went for a route march of 18 miles.

Transfered to Machine Gun Section on 22nd April.
Entry.48:
Web Equipment issued to machine Gun section, socks, Braces and chin strap.

Saturday 24 April, 1915

The 5th Brigade went on route march 18 miles.

The Brigade consisted of 17 - 18 - 19 Battalions of Infantry.

The
Entry.49:
Brigade with Light Horse, Artillery, A.M.C. and French Sailors march through Sydney on a fare well send off.

Total number of Troops present 5,000.

25,000 people to view us, we marched part of the way, From Victoria Markets toStation through the rain.
Entry.54:
Clothes issued this day.

Singlets, Undertrousers, socks, Cholera Belts, Shaving Brush, Razor, Balaclava Caps, Cardigan, Jacket, Hold All, House Wife, Tooth brush, Hair Brush & Comb. Field Dressings. Entrenching toolHead & and Kit Bag.
Entry.55: Water Bottle issued this day & Extra Uniform & trousers.
Entry.111:
Marched from Railway station to boat. Tom came down from G'burn to see me off also Mr McShane & Nita & Hilda Harris.

We went on board at 2.30 left Sydney heads at 5.30.

Transport was the "Ceramic" A40
Entry.118:
The last glimps of Australia, we have come straight across the Bight & come to the coast near Albany, we followed it for about 8 hours & then lost it again.

Wonder if we will ever get another look at it.
Entry.131: have been going across Indian Ocean for the last couple of weeks, caught our first sight of land, part of the coast of Africa.
Entry.132:
arrived at Aden, land sighted at 11.45, left almost immediately, did not enter port.

It was very hazy & windy. I went up the rigging to get a better view & it was all I could do to stop myself being blown down.
Entry.133: entered red sea & passed the Twelve Apositles, only a few isolated patches of land visible.
Entry.135: going through red sea. Terribly hot.
Entry.136: arrived in Suez at 8.30, lay in port all day, Arabs came out in boats selling lollies & cigarettes also curios. A couple of niggers dived for pennies.The coast going up to Suez consists of hugh mountains which appear to be hard sand, looks very pretty owing to curious shapes & colour effects. The harbour is very beautiful when seen early in the morning. All in very high spirits.
Entry.137: Started to pass through Suez canal at 4 a.m. Passed transport A35 returning home with troops. Signal stations in charge of Indian troops are passed at intervals along the canal banks, get my first glimps of camels in their real setting. Reached Port Said at 5 p.m. went ashore, went round the town with one of the English A.M.C. quartered at Port Said got back on board at 11.30 p.m.
Entry.138:
Left Port Said 5 p.m., had a bit of luck at banker yesterday. All sorts of natives came round the boat selling everything you could imagine, they always ask about twice as much as the things are worth.

Port Said is a very busy shipping centre. French & English warvessels are berthed there together with a whole fleet of merchantmen.

The customs house & several other buildings are very fine. There are two paths to the town -The Europeans & Arab Town which lies the other side of the former, you can get there in a cab for 6d.

There is a fine breakwater running out in to the Mediterranean.

The men slept at the 4.7 guns from Port Said to Alexandria in case we were molested by a hostile war vessel.
Entry.139:
Arrived at Alexandria at 4.30, berthed alongside the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers later the Connaught Rangers came into port.

The natives get dirtier & lower in cast all the way along, the best class of Natives are seen at Suez, at Port Said, they are much the same only dirtier & at Alexandria they are just scum.

We only managed to get onto the wharf & saw nothing of the town.

We left for Cairo at 8.30 & arrived at 3 a.m.

When we got into camp we slept on the ground just in our ranks.

We are camped at Heliopolis 8 miles from Cairo, you can see the Cheops Pyramids from here.
Entry.140:
came back to life at day break & had a look round, we have big tents to live in & a wooden mess shed to have our meals in. Should have a good time if it were not for the sand & heat.

Had a look round Heliopolis. Just getting to know our way round.

Had a trip into Cairo arrived home 10.15 p.m.
Entry.141: Took another run into Cairo it is a fine place but the native quarter called by our fellows the "Wasser" is an isore. I was glad to get out of it. Went out to see the Pyramids of Cheops & Spinx.
Entry.142:
Work commences today, most of it is done in the cool & we are allowed to lie down & rest in the hot hours.

The drill hours are from 6 a.m. to 9, lecture in tent from 11 a.m. to 12. Dinner at 1 p.m. drill from 5 p.m. to 7.

We are allowed 8d per day by Egyptian Govt & it is given to us in the shape of tinned fish & fruit etc which we have at midday.
Entry.147:
The Wasar burned by troops.

We left Cairo just before this happened & were glad we were out of it.
Entry.148: Visited Zoological gardens Cairo. Slight disturbance in Heliopolis by troops.
Entry.153: Night march across desert, started 7.45 p.m. dug trenches & marched till midnight. Stood to arms daybreak, marched back to camp 6 a.m.
Entry.154:
Visited Gezeirch Hospital saw Lindsay Waugh & Nurse Chisholm.

Went to see the "Kursale" a big music hall at Cairo. It was a magnificent programme.You are able to smoke & have drinks brought to you while you sit listerning to the performance.
Entry.155:
Visited Mena hospital met Cecil Watts. He is stationed there. He finds it a bit slow.

Had a ride on a camel & donkey, took some snapshots.

Spent the evening listening to Military band in the park.

Went to see the "Kursale" again for the express purpose of hearing a certain song sung by a French girl. I could sit & listen to her singing all night.
Entry.156:
Drill

George Wensor called. He has been in hospital but is right again now, he hopes to go back to his battery soon. He was in Luna Park Hospital.
Entry.158:
Drill

Went into Cairo with George, had a good time, he hopes to go back to the battery on Sunday.
Entry.160:
Received letters from home.

Had a last night out with George. He has bought a fine camera which he is taking back to Gallipoli with him.
Entry.161: Last night in Heliopolis. The only night that I really tried hard to get a good long drink of beer. As it happened I couldn't get away. Stiff luck. Had to go home thirsty.
Entry.162: Started from Heliopolis for the firing line. Received the order to leave 8.15 p.m. Entrained Zetoun at 10.30 on route for Alezandria.
Entry.163: Arrived Alexandria 4.30 a.m. Embarked on the "Sahurnia" Transport at 5.30 a.m. Weighed anchor 6.30 p.m. en route for Lemnos.
Entry.164:
Yesterday & today have been days of missery spent amongst the most apalling state of filth & grime conceivable.

It turns out that the transport originally intended for us broke down & we were sent off on this boat. On her last voyage she carried a cargo of coal, everything you touch is black.

Our rations have for the most part been dry biscuits & bully beef with water. Anything would be an improvement on this.
Entry.165:
Sailing through the Grecian Archipelego. The scenery was grand. The sunset today was a glorious sight. We are zigzaging all the way to safe guard us against submarines.

It is funny to see how the people on the islands build their houses right on the highest points of the hills. It must be a terrible walk to get up to them.
Entry.166:
Arrived at Lemnos at 5 a.m. French torpedo boat guard the entrances. The harbour is closed from sundown to sunrise.

All final instructions have been given we are held ready to move at an hours notice. We have had 200 rounds of ammunition issued, the pack I have to carry weighs over 100 pounds, just think of it. We have to land with this on a beach that is swept by shells from the Turkish. Have given up thinking of the future amliving entirely in the present as no one knows what the next morning will bring forth.

Sailing has been postponed till tomorrow.
Entry.167:
Have been making full preparations for landing. We have to carry everything ourselves even our cooking pots & firewood. I have been given an extra 50 rounds of ammunition to carry. I went in for a swim, you had to dive about 30 feet from the rail to get in.

Have now been put on board the Osmanieh for the final stage of our 11,000 mile journey to the firing line. We left Lemnos at 7.15 p.m.First sighted lights off Cape Helles 11.15, arrived at Gaba Tepe 12.30. Action was in progress which resulted in the occupation by Australians of a hill. Marched with full equipment & gunsto Reserve Gully. Visited early in morning the N.Z. Battery & had some shots at the Turks from advanced shelters.

Have found out that the hill was not occupied last night as supposed.
Entry.168:
Warships fired a few rounds in the morning, in afternoon a heavy attackwas made on enemys trenches in the direction of hill 971 covered by the guns of the fleet & land batteries. The Turkishguns were hopelessly out classed & duly made very feeble reply. The shooting of the British was exquisite. They turned about 4 square miles into a veritable inferno using luddite & shrapnel. At times the dust & debris was so great as to resemble a fierce dust storm. We watched the fun from the high cliffs near Mt Camel in spite of the number of spent bullets that came our way, which were calmly ignored by the boys. We are advancing now to man the reserve trenches, it will be our first taste of real fire.

We slept behind the line of trenches. We were in a bad position, spent & stray bullets fell amongst us while we slept & we lost several men.

This bombardment was when the English Yeomanry advanced under shrapnel to Chocolate Hill.
Entry.169:
18th Battn badly cut up by the M.G. while charging, several companies almost annihilated. We moved into the reserve trenches & had to pass over 400 yards exposed to shrapnel. The enemy had the range down inch & inflicted about 20 casualties on us.

The trenches so far are very poor, it is just as well there are no snipers about or we would lose heavily, as it is we have lost about 12 by stray bullets. I was sent twice for water & had to pass right in the track of stray bullets fired on the trenches on our right.

Our men are being very roughly handled so are the N.Z. They & the Indians are easily the best regiments out here. They are obeying the officers very well.

We have many more guns than the Turks but they are well concealed & the country is so broken that it is almost impossible to locate them. We have only lost 1 officer so far. I don't mind this work a bit. The bullets are not so bad.

Capt Fitzpatrick killed in action.
Entry.170:
Have been talking to some Ghurkas. We cooked our breakfast in the trenches, water is scarce but we have been well supplied with food so far.

We have been busy improving our trenches all day. A few stray shots have come our way but no one has been hurt, we have had plenty of food & water.

We are still 700 yards behind the firing line. We have had several casualties. The enemy have sent a few shrapnel shells against our trenches, severly wounding one man.

The Gurrkas made a slight advance during the night and
the stray bullets have been very bad. We are becoming expert cooks, with the limited utensils at our disposal.
Entry.171:
Trench routine, carrying water, going on fatigues, etc.

Was in charge of a guard of three last night. The Ghurkas attached & made a slight advance. Slept in a dugout part of the night & a trench the rest. Stray bullets kept giving you a cold feeling down the small of the back, as we are right behind the fire trench & as most of the bullets go high in the night our trench gets a rough time after dark.
Entry.172:
Was sent to the base for overcoats about 6 miles altogether. We were sniped at more than was comfortable. I carried the coats on the side nearest the enemy, "just in case". In the afternoon I had to dig a gun position & deepen a trench.

Our dinner consisted of boiled rice, biscuits, jam, bovril & bully beef, with tea. I was cook for Mac & I.

Slept out in the open all night, was glad of my overcoat. It is considered bad form to run here or to duck - for anything except shrapnel, anything is permissable for that. In fact when we had to go out in the open under shrapnel one chap dropped what he was carrying & beat it for his life. The next day, the general came along & frightened seven years growth out of him. Told him he could have him shot for it, but he said he'd do it again under similar circumstances.
Entry.173:
Have had a hot time with shrapnelin the morning. I went to the beach for a swim in the morning, was shelled there & all the afternoon until dark they peppered our trenches with them we had surprisingly few casualties. At 7.30 we had to change our position. 14 of us were separated from the rest & had to sleep out amongst the stray bullets. It is pretty nerveracking for bullets to snick into the ground within a few feet of you, coming apparently from nowhere. We have had a bad time so far, our battallion has lost about 50 men & have not had a chance to fire a shot.

Moving with the machine guns is no joke, all gear & ammunition is carried by hand. I often wonder if they made a mistake in my papers & think I signed on as a carthorse.
Entry.174:
We are holding "Courtneys Post" near the extreme right of the Australian position. There are Turkish trenches on every side of us. It makes you a bit shaky for a while to hear bullets thudding into the sandbags a couple of feet from your head or shells shrieking over the hill into Popes Post 200 yards away.

The Indians out here are very cool customers. It isgreat see them plodding along with the mules taking no more notice of the bullets than if they were flies.

This place is a regular network of trenches, you could easily lose yourself in them. They are 8 feet deep in the front line & they need to be for they are being fired into day & night.

Had a swim at Hell Spit this afternoon. Expected to be shelled any minute but was determined to have a dip.
Entry.175:
Should have been a day of rest but it has been the greatest battering we have had since I have been here. We blew upa Turkish sap a few yards away from our gun pit, we just got out in time. The charge exploded as we came out of the tunnel. Water is the great problem here. We have to carry all we drink for over a mile.

I had Les Payhem over for a yarn today, I was very glad to see him.

Shells have been crashing into our position all day. There are a couple of guns we can't locate & they are a veritable thorn in our side, you hear thewhizz bang of shrapnel at the most unexpected times & places. You never know when one will come close enough to put you out of action.

Great engineering skill has been used in making the valley as safe as possible. There must be 5 miles of saps 6 ft deep & 4 ft wide dug by the infantry at night.

Friday 27th August, 1915

Still lost, I had to go & forage for rations for 14 men. I got 2 loaves of bread, a big lump of bacon, two tins of jam & some tea & sugar & as we have finished them offI feel much more cheerful.

We found a N.Zlander who happened to be going to the same place as us so he offered to guide us. After tremendous labour we got our guns to their position which was at Popes Post only 20 yards from the
German
Turkish trenches. We have to do a permanent guard3 hours on & 6 hours off.

We get well fed here & have good facilities for cooking. We even had some jam & cheese, both on the same piece of bread,

Snipers are bad here. Won't be surprised to get a bullet in the head sometimes when I am going round a corner. There is a telephone here. Our gun is in an underground dugout. There is a dead Turks leg sticking out of the ground 5 feet from my face, not too pleasant.
Entry.176:
6 men were sent out to get our kit bags which we had to discard last Monday. Mac & I had a swim. Itspleasures were somewhat marred by a few shells from "Beachy Bill".

Our shifts have been changed. Each man does 2 hrs on & 6 off. We go on at night from 6 to 8 & then from 2 to 4. At 4 o'clock all men have to stand to arms till 5, we can then have a couple of hours sleep till 7 so it is no picnic here.

The Turks are sending the shells closer to our camp every day. This afternoon one lobbed only 60 yards away. We are expecting one through the roof next. We are badly off for news, have not had a letter for over a fortnight.

I hope to have a shave tomorrow, first for a fortnight. I look a regular hero with all that growth on.

Some Italian officers have been floating about here & there is a rumour that they are landing 30,000 men, lets hope so as it will end this all the quicker.
Entry.177:
A most strenuous day. Carried water in the morning, sent to base for packs at 2.15 p.m. arrived back 7.15 on guard from 8 to 10 & 2 to 4. I had to stand to arms at 4 a.m.

Heavy firing broke out against our trenches at 8.30 & lasted till 9 p.m. This was evidently a blind to hide operations in the centre where a furious fire was heard. We have not heard what happened but presume it was an attack by the Turks. The demonstration against our trenches took the form of a heavy shower of bombs. Both sides used flares as it was a very dark night. We spent a very tense half hour, expecting to have to bring the gun into action at any minute but things died down without the enemy taking the offensive.

Met Nev Hodgens, have to see him tomorrow afternoon.

A lot of our chaps are crook none serious but those who are well have a lot of extra work to do.
Entry.178:
Nothing much doing. Camp routine.

While on watch from 4 to 6 p.m. I witnessed a lively little bomb throwing match between our chaps & the Turks at Quinns Post. Our chaps won on points but I don't think much damage was done on either side.
Entry.180:
& 18th Batts came to Monash Gully to relieve some of the Regiments who have been here for a long time.

Turkish aeroplane flew over our trenches reconnoitering in the evening.

The enemy kept up a heavy rifle & shell fire all night knocking our parapet about in places.

Wrote to Mater & Mignonette.
Entry.181:
Have been crook today.

Expected an attack at night. We have no supports at all & only 4 men to each post in the firing line, we would have had a bad time if they had given it a fly. As it was they opened up an exceptionally heavy rifle & machine gun fire which had no effect except making us a bit more watchful.

Saturday 2 September, 1915

Still off duty, for talk of a Turkish attack. 18th Batt came up as reserves, nothing eventuated.

Have heard that Capt Fitzpatrick is not dead but is suffering from nervous breakdown. Bob Dryden is safe, have been having a yarn to him, he has had a pretty exciting time.
Entry.182:
One man killed in trenches. It is now getting very cold at night. Aforetaste of what we may expect later on.

The usual bombardment by the enemy. We aregetting quite used to this now & take no notice.

Am well again today.

Roast meat for dinner a rare treat, makes you think you are back at home.
Entry.183:
Have been taking things as easily as possible.

Made pancakes for all the boys today which were duly appreciated.

Are beginning to feel quite old soldiers now & take bombardments & stray bullets very calmly indeed.
Entry.184:
Received letters from home & papers.

Letters from Gibby, Mrs Parish (2), Jessie Chilsholm, Ollie Turner, Phyllis Floden, & Mater & Ida.

Went down & had a yarn to Bob Dryden. Cheered his heart by giving Tobacco, Matches & Cigarette Papers. His battalion are having a rest down Monash Gully.

The 24th Batt arrived last night as support to the
Entry.185: who are so weak in numbers that no man has a chance of being out of the firing line day or night
Entry.186:
Have made a seperate dugout for ourselves. Mac, I & Bernie Norris. Mac is pretty crook in the stomach but seems to be improvong. The 21st Batt relieved the 24th. They are very raw men & allowed a Turk to get into our trenches early in the Morning.

21st Batt were torpedoed outside Lemnos & lost the Brigadier & about 40 men.

Thursday 9 September, 1915

Wrote to Mother, Ada & Gibby.

Mac has been crook all day but thinks he is getting better.

Went down for water & lay about the rest of the day in our dugout, which is a regular little home.

The Turkish guns have been very quiet lately. I think they must have been located. Only one of them has fired at all during the last few days.
Entry.187:
Named our dugout. It has the distinction of being the first place on "Courtneys" to have a name. It's monica is "Kangarooma"

Two men of the 8th collected last night. It was their last watch before going away for a rest, a case of "stiff knees".

Have been doing a bit of cooking today. I got hold of a tin of milk. Breakfast, bread & milk, Dinner, boiled rice & tea rissoles. Quite an elaborate diet for here.

A bomb burst just outside our gun pit last night & a piece came through the opening passing between myself & the chap who was on with me. You don't seem to be safe here anywhere lately.
Entry.188:
Watches changed, have to do 18 hours on & 18 hours off.

Heavy firing during night. It is reported that Hill 971 & the railway have been captured. If that is so we may safely anticipate an early move from here.

Scored a tin of concentrated cream & made some rice & milk which was very acceptable, am looking forward to a repitition if I can get good with the Quartermaster Sgt who has a couple of cases.

It continues cold, especially at night. The artillery on both sides was very active during the afternoon, several shells landed on Courtneys.

We find our dugout a great blessing you get a bit of peace & quietness.

One of our men, Gibson, has been sent to Lemnos suffering from Dysentry. This is the first man we have lost.
Entry.189:
Had a shave, made a great find in the shape of a pair of socks, I only had those I stood up in before.

Scored another tin of milk & had some more rice & milk. Mac had some & reckoned it was all right.

The weather is cold & dull, would not be surprised to see some rain.

Mac had a "chat" hunt & got 13, he expects to have a comfortable nights sleep tonight.

Very light shower of rain during the night. Heavy bombardment by the fleet on the right.

Wrote to Mrs Ray, Mr Maguire & Mr Chauvel.
Entry.190:
Another man sent to Lemnos, Pte Simpson.

A very hard day, two trips to the beach, shelled both times, the second time the shells were going all round me but most of them went in the water & failed to explode. I had only been back from my second trip & hour & a half before going into the gun pit all night.

Met Paddy Matthews & Les Payton down on the beach & had a yarn to them.

Water has been very short lately for some reason or other & what we do get is very salty.

It was very cold on watch on the gun during the night but I managed to get a fair amount of sleep so do not feel too bad this morning.

The artillery on both sides has been very lively. Pte Halfford, one of our men got a slight graze from a bullet on the head, the first man we have had touched.
Entry.191:
Very dull & cold. Very lively artillery duel, our guns firing about 6 times to the Turks one. We got a burst of shrapnel on our hill from goodness knows where as the Turks can never get a shell there, it must have been a badly timed shell from our own guns.

Have had a long guard to do, have been on duty 4 out of 18 hours it is too much as we have to go on fatigue work, carrying water when we come off.

We are getting all this extra work because so many men are sick.
Entry.192:
Slight shower of rain during the night made everything sloppy & uncomfortable.Had to go off sick today just a touch of dysentery, I hope to be well again tomorrow.

They are putting a fourth man in our happy home, it will be a bit crowded.

Have been put on a rice diet. Wrote home & to Jessie Chisholm, Tom, Mrs Parish & Phyllis today.

Have been pretty crook & off duty, had a good nights sleep.
Entry.193:
Letters from home. Mater, Dot & a very nice one from Beryl.

Am right once more & will go on duty next watch. The watches have been changed from 18 to 24 hrs.

The chaps in the big shed started to mend the roof & had half of it off when the rain came on & gave them a bad time of it.Had a sharp shower which however did not last long.

The Turks turned their attention to our post last night, one shell which failed to explode landed very close to our quarters. About a dozen others landed on the crest of the hill.Stray bullets occasionally fall about our humpy, one came very close during the night & made us feel a bit uncomfortable.
Entry.194:
On duty again.Very hard work carrying sandbags up the hill & finishing the mending of the roof of the big shed. Finished that & am building a shelter for the cook.

Scored one egg. Great rejoicing. Very slight shower of rain.

Wrote to Ida.
Entry.195:
Carried water. Four of us built a shelter for one of the gun numbers. I had a pretty rotten job emptying sandbags over the side of a steep hill in full view of the enemys trenches, was sniped at but they were rotten shots & couldn't get within a foot of me. Anyhow the officer made me get down.

The Turks opened a furious artillery & rifle fire at 5.15 & lasting for 20 minutes. The air seemed alive with bullets & the concussion almost made one sick. They got one of our poor chaps through the head & another was hit by a shell.

I have to go on watch at 6 p.m., one of the men has just gone sick.

The Turks made a big attack on the left but were beaten back with heavy loss, that was the reason of the demonstration against this post.
Entry.196:
Very tired only had about 3 hours sleep. It was a lovely moonlight night, one bullet hit right in the opening of our pit & a piece of cut the boot of a man I was talking to in the trench.

Received a letter from Mrs Parish with some little trinkets from Australia Day which I was glad to receive. Had to go & get the mail with the O.C. It was a long climb & I had quite a lot to lug about.

Had to move to another shed but we have fenced off and have the little home which has the same name as before.

Cigarettes issued today. Amate of Bernie Norrises came into our new house, his name is George Ball.
Entry.197:
Crook again. Had to go down & bring about 40 lbs of meat up the hill. This finished me.

Two men killed & 6 wounded by one of our own bombs.

Things were very quiet, it has been a lovely warm day & a bright moonlight night.

One of our destroyers lay out in the moonlight, right close to the shore, trying to tempt Beachy Bill to have a shot. As soon as he had he would have been blown sky high by a monitor carrying a 14" gun & lying right out to sea waiting to locate it by the flash but Mr Turk is too shrewd to fire at night & give the position away.
Entry.198:
Still off Duty.

Received a letter from the mater.

Artillery is very active lately, fleet as well as land batteries.

Rum was issued.

The Island of Imbros is a beautiful sight just before dark. The sun goes down just to the right of it & it looks a very dark blue & eventually fades away, growin the same colour as the sea.
Entry.199:
Still off duty.

It continues cold in the mornings.

Lay about all day.
Entry.200:
Leon Ferguson wounded.

The big shed caught fire, several chaps were burnt out of house & home i.e. their rifles, equipment & overcoats went.

The ships were very active during the night & sent a number of heavy shells into the Turks.

We are building a new cook house for the cook to keep out the weather.

It was very cold during the night & windy in the evening.
Entry.201:
On duty again.

Carried up rations.

There was a demonstration by us at night together with the guns of the fleet & land batteries. The Turks made a very spirited reply.

The two machine guns were going we had a cross feed in No 2 gun which took a good deal of fixing. Flame absorbers had been made for both guns but collapsed after a few rounds. The Turks exploded a mine, trying to destroy one of our saps, which they failed to do. The Turks use a very fine flare for night use. It gives out a pale yellow light lasting about 2 minutes it floats right down in front of our trenches making every part of them show up. They are only used in case of a demonstration by us.
Entry.202:
On guard.

Had a talk to Lieut Wright. He is acting B.M.G.O. . He is looking well.

Had a shave & a wash. Feel a new man.

Bread & cigarettes issued today. It is nice & warm in the sun today.
Entry.203:
Went to church & Holy Communion.

Two friends of Bernie Morris came up in the evening.

I received G'burn papers. They were very welcome and I did not know what to do with myself so I had a good long read of G'burn news.

Today especially in the afternoon, has been the quietest that I can remember, it was just like a Sunday afternoon at home.
Entry.204:
On guard for 24 hours.

Very good war news is coming through from the European theatre, also things are pointing to a big move here shortly which will be eagerly welcomed even if it does mean some hard fighting as we are all fed up with doing nothing.

The weather continues warm much to our satisfaction.

A very ingenious musical instrument has been constructed by one of the stretcher bearers. It consists of about a dozen empty condensed milk tins which he has tuned up. He uses a couple of little sticks to play them with. So far I have heard him play Home Sweet Home, The Swanee River, On the Mississippi & God Save The King so they are not too bad.

I was given a few lollies & a couple of books today. Truly a glorious haul.
Entry.205:
Fatigue work getting wood. Had a real good wash in fresh water, first decent one I have had since goodness knows when.

The Turks have rigged up some new guns & gave one of the guns of our mountain battery hell, about one hundred shells in all. Their shooting was excellent. They have also raked up a heavy gun from somewhere. It sent shrapnel down Monash Gully & got a couple of our chaps.

There is a constant growling from the guns of the fleet on the right & we are expecting big things to happen there shortly.

Went & had a yarn with Capt Fitzgerald. He is well. Found out that Harrison & Maxwell are both wounded. Also that Capt Fitzpatrick made a very poor showing.

Had bacon & two eggs for 
breakfast
tea. It was First Class.
Entry.206:
On guard again.

It is a glorious morning. Just like a morning in December at home only not so hot. I am thoroughly enjoying it.

The rumble of the warships guns on the right is now incessant. They are miles away from us & yet the ground seems to tremble when they are fired.

Mac took some papers to Capt Fitzgerald & in the goodness of his heart gave him pretty near all we had in the place. So we are stranded for spare paper till next mail, I'll see that he isn't so kind hearted next time.

We have been told that we will be out of here by November but in the words of the Scotchman "I hae ma doots".

The 17th Field team of siege Artillery gave "Abdul" a surprise. They landed about 12 very high explosive shells in the Chess Board. They were just like young earthquakes.
Entry.207:
I had come to the end of my envelopes & had been promised one by one of the 21st​. Last night he had an eye knocked out by a bullet so I went up to his mate & told him about it & said as the chap would not be coming back he would have no further use for them so he could give me a few. I got 8 altogether & some writing paper. "It's an ill wind - etc".

Changed my sox today, I have worn them day & night for six weeks. "This is the life". The fun of it is that I would not have been able to have a change yet only that I picked up a dirty pair that someone else had thrown away.

Bread issued today.

It is my 24 hrs off & I am taking things easy.

The fleet continue to keep up a heavy fire on the right.

Two new aeroplanes recconoitred the Turkish positions under a heavy shrapnel fire.
Entry.208:
Another glorious morning. We are truly in lucks way as far as the weather is concerned. At 7 a.m. there was a great cloud of mist over the completely hiding it.

Am on guard again.

Mr Wright came round & was examining the gun position.

Mac went to see Capt Fitzgerald in the afternoon.

Things in general have been very quiet today. The artillery in particular has been very light.
Entry.209: Have been crook all day, feel to weak to do anything, have had only Bovril & as there is no bread with it, it is pretty thin tack.
Entry.210:
Have been given clearance certificate which will take me off the Peninsula. I am sorry in a way because I don't like leaving my pals but I am too jolly weak to do anything. Mac & Bernie helped me down to the beach hospital.

Mail came in today. Had a letter from Beryl & Hilda. I am very disappointed at not getting one from the Mater.

As soon as I got to the beach hospital Beachy sent a shrapnel along which spattered all over the cases that we were behind & hit one man in the arm, just a few yards away & later killed a man in swimming.

Went aboard S.S. Hospital Ship Assaye.

Had a bit of stiff luck, lost my watch, may be lucky enough to get it back.

Met Bunny Abbot & Arthur Taylor.
Entry.211:
Very heavy bombardment in the Anzac zone by both sides.

Am very comfortable here. The food is first class & everyone tries to do all they can for you. Have had a shave & bath. I hope I don't catch a cold (?).

Am just lying about all the time yarning & reading.

I am sorry in a way at being away from the firing line but I was not much use there as I was.
Entry.212:
Left Anzac for Lemnos at 5.45. Sailed along the Gallipoli Peninsula & had a view of it. It is enormously strong. Saw an army dirrigable airship. It followed us to Lemnos.

Arrived in Lemnos 10 p.m.
Entry.213:
Arrived at Lemnos last night & find that our destination is Malta. I would rather go to Alexandria.

Saw a submarine in the harbour also the Mauritania, the second largest ship afloat.

Left Lemnos for Malta at 6 p.m. after putting the Indians ashore.
Entry.214:
Sailing through Mediterranean Ocean. Passed through the Ionian Islands and round the end of Greece.

The weather is beautifully warm, the sea is as calm as a mill pond & looks the darkest blue imaginable.
Entry.215:
Ran into a regular thunderstorm at 9 a.m. All our bedding got wet but we managed to keep our blankets dry. The rain cleared off by dinner time & the things soon dried off.

Am getting a bit tired of the ship & will be glad to get ashore.
Entry.216:
Arrived at Malta at 5 a.m. The town is very picturesque & is built more on the Moorish style than anything else. Went right across the bay for orders then came back to Valetta harbour. It is all artificial work & is very picturesque though dirty.

There were 6 big French ships of war in the harbour, we gave them a cheer as we went past.

I got some fine photographs of the harbour. The usual bumboats came round the ship selling chocolate. All the little pulling boats in the harbour are like the Italian Gondola, only smaller.

We expect to disembark in the morning.

We started coaling but stopped again almost immediately.
Entry.217:
Disembarked at 11.30.

Took some more interesting snaps & saw a submarine in dry dock but couldn't get a photo of it.

Cigarettes & matches were given us as we came ashore also some milk.

We were put in a motor ambulance & then followed a drive of about ¾ of an hour right across the island to St Georges Hospital. It was a lovely spin & all the roads are perfect so we were able to go at a good pace. The hospital we are in was formely a barracks & it is very comfortable. I am in Ward B2.

There is some great scenery here & I am anxious to get loose amongst it with my camera.
Entry.218:
Met Norm Matthews, he has been here six weeks & is going to England, lucky chap.

Lord & Lady Methuenwith their daughter visited the hospital. They were very decent & we were very pleased to see them.

Managed to borrow a bob off Norm, the first money I have had in my pocket for 2 months, it was truly the "Breaking of the Drought". We get paid 2/- per week here but we can get more when we go into the convalescent camp.

The situation in the Balkans is in a pretty serious condition. By the way things are going there will probably be a big upheavel there shortly. I hope that it turns out all right.
Entry.219: Lord & Lady Methuen with their daughter visited the hospital. They were very nice but I think he was more afraid of me than I was of him anyhow he seemed jolly nervous.
Entry.238: Broke out of Hospital & went into Valletta. Stoney broke. Had a good look round & walked home.
Entry.240:
Sent to All Saints Convalescent Camp.

Nearly eaten alive with fleas.

Had the first glass of beer I have had for 11 weeks.
Entry.241:
No money, managed to live somehow till dinner time, after dinner I sold a pair of boots for 2/6 which will keep me alive till pay day.

Had to get up at 1 a.m. & throw my bedding outside. I got dressed & slept in my overcoat. I am one big flea bite all over.
Entry.242:
Tried to see the paymaster about getting some extra money & found him a very hard man to see. Had to give it up till next week.

Some of the prices in Malta are worth noting. Shave 1d., 100 good cigarettes 1/-, a decent cigar 1d., Haircut 2d., beer 2½ pint. It is a big contrast to Egypt. Have felt pretty crook today.

The meal hours are breakfast 7.30, Dinner 12.45, Tea 4 p.m. We have our tea just about the time that people at home are having afternoon tea in their drawing room.

The meal consists of bread & butter & has to last 15½ hours. Just think of it.
Entry.243:
Pay day: Drew £1, first pay of over 2/- since Aug 9th.

Went into Valletta. "Did ourselves well".

Went to chapple of bones, took a couple of snaps, arrived home at 9.45.

Had the first game of billiards I have had since Egypt.
Entry.244:
Raised £1 off the Paymaster, went into town, got the O.C's photos, arrived back at 10 p.m.

Had a look through the Armoury.
Entry.245: Stayed in camp & played cards, won 6/-.
Entry.246:
Went into Valletta & made arrangements to have our teeth done.

Had a good time. Put R.M.L.I. badges in our caps so we could get beer served to us but it wouldn't work much.

Visited the Admiralty arrived home early 8.20 p.m.
Entry.247: Came into Valletta again. Had a pretty fine time. Nothing doing about our teeth, went home jolly near stone penniless.
Entry.248:
Had a walk half way to Sliema Ferry, collected £2-10/- in town. Had a royal time, bought a bed in town at the Connaught Sailors home.

Thursday
Entry.249:
Are making hay while the sun shines. Sid Moss, a chap from the 13th M.G. have chummed up. We left the Sailors home at 7.45 a.m. had breakfast & went & played billiards & drank beer till lunch time. We then went & sent a wire to Sids people at Gibraltar for £5. After that we took a ride on hired bikes about 3 miles out, at a wayside pub we patronised with the Maltese. I took photos of the mob & gave out "picture cards" to a lot of school kiddies. On the way back all went well till we were nearly home, then Sid ran into a donkey & almost immediately after, into me. There was a terrible mix up. The police took a whole host of names. It cost us a dollar between us to square matters.

Slept at "Hotel De France" Valletta.
Entry.250:
Arrived in camp at 10 a.m., had not been missed though we had been away two days.

Pay Day drew 10/-.

Went into Valletta for the night.
Entry.251:
Went into Valletta, went the pace. Slept at the Hotel De France.

Went out to see Mac at Cottania hospital. He & Bernie Norris have been there since Nov 2nd.

I received 14 letters.
Entry.252:
Still in Valletta, still having a good time, put in the night at the same old place.

Met two Maltese girls at a Restaurant, we are going to take them to the pictures tomorrow night.
Entry.253:
Still in Valletta but running short of cash. Met Mac & Norrie at 2.30 spent the afternoon with them.

Went & had tea & fooled round playing billiards etc. Took a run out to Mesieda when we got to the ferry the last boat had gone so we went over in a gondola, we got back to camp at 1.30 a.m. We had only been in camp about 5 hours since Wednesday.

Everything was O.K. & we hadn't been missed.
Entry.254: Socked the paymaster for £4.10/- so will soon be financial again.
Entry.255:
In 
Malta
Valletta went out to Pieta & found Cassie & Paula. Took them out to Sliema arrived at the Hotel at 12.30 a.m. pretty tired.
Entry.256:
Had to come back to camp for medical injection. Was put in "C" Section. Went straight into Valletta after that. Went to Pieta at 2.30. Took the girls photo dressed in our clothes. We put on their skirts meanwhile.

We stayed till 10.30. I had to take "Mem" into Valletta as she was disappointed by her two friends.

Got to Hotel De France 12 midnight. We should have got to camp that night but we risked it & stayed in all night.
Entry.257:
Went in for our pay & came out to Valletta again in the afternoon.

We met a corporal out of our hut & took him round with us. We went to the Olympia Club & played billiards.

Sid & the corporal went back to Camp, I stayed at the Hotel De France.
Entry.258:
Sid came out in the morning & met me. I was just having breakfast at the Hotel at 10 a.m.

We went & played billiards till dinner time then we went out to see the girls at Pieta, stayed at the hotel all night.
Entry.259:
Met a petty officer at breakfast at Hotel De France. He was out at one of the Submarines that had got into the sea of Marmora.

We took him to the club & he made us have lunch with him.

In the afternoon we went out to Pieta where we stayed till 1.30 a.m. We had no money but we fixed things up at the Hotel De France. We said we would fix up on pay day.
Entry.260:
There had been a terrible storm during the night & no ferrys were running so we had to go across in a dicer or rowing boat. We just had 1/3 to pay for our garry back to camp.

Everything had been flooded there, but luckily my blankets had kept fairly dry so I managed to get a good sleep.
Entry.261: Went into Valletta to collect £5 that was coming to Sid. Wrote a letter to Pieta saying that we were coming out tomorrow, played billiards & went to the pictures, put in the night at the Hotel De France.
Entry.262: Fooled round in the morning. Met the girls in the afternoon & stayed at their place till 12 o'clock. Stayed at the Hotel again.
Entry.263:
Sid had to meet Carrie & take her out rowing. I went out to see Mac at Cottonera. He & Bernie both expect to be sent to convalescent camp shortly.

I played billiards after tea & met Sid after he had left his club.

We slept at the Hotel as usual.
Entry.264:
Money running short again, it's a hard world! Fortunately it is pay day so we will be able to restore our financial position to its former glory (10/- each?).

I went out to see my girl at Pieta. Sid took his over to Sliema so I did not see him again that night.He went out to camp but I dossed in the usual place.
Entry.265:
Met Sid at the Olympia Club at about 10.45. He beat me at billiards for the first time.

Money being short I had dinner & came back to camp & left Sid to look up some friends etc as he still had a few bob left.

I called into St Georges hospital & gave the nurses some prints of some photos I had taken a few days before.

I came back to camp just in time as I had been wanted & was told to report so I did & was told to hold myself ready to go to Goza an island a few miles from Malta. I will try & get out of it.
Entry.266: Terribly cold have been doing a shiver all day, it is the coldest day we have had here yet.
Entry.267:
The weather is much warmer now. We opened our tent up & pulled our beds out to give them an airing in the sun.

Sid has been floating round Valletta on his own account for the last couple of days. He landed up in the guard tent this morning.

The Maltese Malitia set on some of our boys & nearly killed one, he was hit on the head with an iron chair.
Entry.268:
Nothing doing all day, but after tea all the boys went down to Sliema to have revenge on the Maltese Militia who kept out of the way.

The boys marched home after making a good deal of noise but doing no damage.
Entry.269:
Our lads again assulted by the Malitia, they were pelted with shrapnel from a bridge that runs across the road, one man had to go to hospital. They are afraid our lads will run amock so they are sending all the fit men away in the morning.

I went into Valletta to see if Sid was still at Cottonerahospital & found that he was so I spent the evening at Pieta & slept at the Hotel De France "on tick".
Entry.270:
Sid came out of the guard room. He was to go away with the batch leaving today but was told to wait till the next lot.

About 150 men went back from All Saints camp today.
Entry.271:
Sent to Gozo. Up at 5.15, a breakfast by candlelight & a drive down to the boat in the grey dawn. It felt like being at the front again. Our boat left at 6.30 & arrived at Gozo at about 8.30. Our quarters are in barracks in an old fort here. I have been put in No 3 Section.

I am with a New Zealander who knows Ernie Kennedy in N.Z.

The name of the fort is Fort Shambray .

Did my weeks pay at cards.
Entry.272:
The weather here is great. In the morning everything is fresh, just like spring. There is nothing much to do here except play cards. Just at present I have gone broke on the game. I had some good games of handball today, the first time I have tried it, my hands are pretty sore. This place is a veritable gambling hell, wherever you go you see little crowds round a bed & hear the clink of coins.

I played till about 1 a.m.
Entry.273:
Did not go to church, played cards instead, am very stiff from handball.

Knocked of playing cards at about 12 p.m.
Entry.274:
We all went for a bit of a route march in the morning, we went about 3 miles all together & had a pint of beer given to us when we got back & it went well, it is the first I have had since I have been on Gozo.

Cards again after dinner & right on till about 3.30 a.m. I am beginning to get a bit of cash back which is very gratifying.Every one gambles here & it is very funny to see chaps who have never done any of it before catch the fever, after a very few sittings they are just as bad as the rest.
Entry.275:
Am jolly tired from 
base
handball & late hours but am still playing cards, knocked off early, got to bed at about 10.30.
Entry.276:
Was pretty tired this morning had a bit of a read & played cards till dinner time.

Played handball in the afternoon, also after tea then we had a game of cards for about an hour. At present I am showing a total cash balance of 7/- out of 10/- I had on Friday so I am not doing too badly.
Entry.277:
Had a quiet day, played handball in the morning & had a rest. In the afternoon I had another game of handball & I read.

Went to bed early (for a wonder).
Entry.278:
Was on fatige, about 2 hours work.

Pay day. Had a good game of cards.
Entry.279:
A draft went back to Malta including some of the chaps I had chummed up with in our room. I took their photos & they are going to get them developed in Valletta.

Still playing handball.
Entry.280:
Took on a regular fatige of sweeping down steps & turned it in again because it was too much like hard work.

Had a very fierce game of cards won 10/- & a wristlet watch making 22/- altogether.

At 2 a.m. the military police came & were going to take our names for having a light burning after "Lights Out". There was a terrible scatter in the dark. I ended up under someones bed with the police looking for me with matches but he didn't find me although he nearly fell over me.

We do lead a fast life in the Army - What?
Entry.281: More excitement, went into the chief village of Gozo - Victoria. We should have been back by 6 p.m. but thought it too early so we did not return till 8.30 & had to climb a 60 foot wall in the semi darkness, was not at all sorry when we were in as the climb is a bit trying even in daylight as one slip means a drop on to hard concrete below.
Entry.282: It has come up cold & blowy with showers, occasionally it was pretty rough on the water but the boat came all right though we didn't expect it, we had to mope about all day as it was too rotten outside to do anything.
Entry.283:
Still cold & wet. I have a bit of a cold & am not feeling too bright.

The weather was too rough for the boat to come in, it is the first time it has missed since I have been here.
Entry.284:
Got a letter from Bill How from All Saints. He was a New Zealander who was in the same room as myself & we got rather chummy.

I was speaking at a debate this evening & I won the decision. We had a very enjoyable evening.

Still no boat, had to have bully beef for dinner & it was pretty hard to tackle.
Entry.285: Pay day. I owed 5/6 & had 1/- owed to me. I finished up with 3/-, had some good games of handball. I am beginning to feel fit again as my wind improves every day.
Entry.286: Cricket match, men v Sergeants, men won by about 100 runs, I made 8.
Entry.287: Played cards most of the day. It is cold & miserable.
Entry.288:
Left Gozo for All Saints, I was not in the draft but I went & got put on. We left Gozo at 2 p.m. arrived at Malta at 4.30, put in No 1 Section.

Mac had lef All Saints today. I said things.

The rules have been made more stringent here now but I hope to find a way of getting over the difficulty.
Entry.289:
Put in isolation because smallpox had broken out at Gozo.

Pinched into Valletta without a pass. Went out to Pieta & came back to camp at about 12.30 a.m. I brought a flask of Cognac back for the boys & it was duly appreciated.

They are very strict here now & it took me all my time to beat the pickets.
Entry.290:
Loafed about all day, tried to get some warm clothing but couldn't.

We had our Christmas concert at 7 p.m. Lord Methuen was in attendance & it went off very well.
Entry.291:
Drew our pay.

I went into Pieta to see Paula. Now that Sid Moss has gone back I have to get out on my own. It was a hard job beating the picket as none of those in isolation are supposed to have passes but I got home all right at about 12.30.
Entry.292:
Played cards all day. Weare living in anticipation of our Christmas dinner tomorrow for which great preparations are being made.

The weather continues very pleasant so we have nothing to grumble about.
Entry.293: Had a first class dinner & a beano in the tent after. We got a bottle of "Scotch" from the Sergeants Mess for 5/6. At about 4.30 we decided to go out so we took a trip to Mesieda , we were all nice & merry when we started to drive home, about 4 miles, I was up on top of the Garry with the driver & while we were going up a hill the horse slewed round & upset the whole bally show. I had the farthest to fall but luckily nobody was hurt but I am keeping a bit of the broken garry as a suvenir. After that we had a real good supper & half a dozen bottles of beer for luck. We had a real good time.
Entry.294: Stayed at home, had a good rest & a game of cards, DeMattos & Sheen went out so I went to bed at about 7 p.m. I had a good nights sleep which I needed badly.
Entry.295: Went out to Pieta to see Mrs Grundy & Paula. Took their photos & had a good time. They all had to go out after tea so I stayed & minded the house till they came home at about 9.30. We then stayed & yarned till 11.30 when I started to walk home, 4 miles. I brought home a bottle of Scotch for the boys & we all startedin & nearly finished it at about 1 a.m. when I got home.
Entry.296:
Not feeling too bright after the "cratur" last night. Didn't get up till dinner time as I had a thick head. At lunch time we got a free issue of beer given us by the Major.

I rested all the afternoon & had a game of cards after tea. I got to bed at about 10 o'clock & slept like a top. I have a bit of a cold just now but otherwise I am very fit.

It is very hard to get winter clothes. I only have a shirt & my jacket & it is very cold if you are out at night as I often am.
Entry.297: Went out to Pieta, came home rather early went to the pictures & had a few drinks. Arrived home at about 10 p.m.
Entry.298: Killed time as best I could, got our pay. I had a few shillings owing to me, played cards & won some more.
Entry.299:
Went into Valletta, De Mattos & Sheen, two friends of mine managed to get a few shillings which was nearly all spent.

Coming home we met two nurses & took them home to St Patrick's Hospital.

Were too tired to see the New Year in so we went to bed at 11.30.

Turn to
